This thiamine diphosphate dependent enzyme and the enantio-complementary benzaldehyde lyase (BAL) from P. fluorescens can be used as biocatalysts to synthesise with high enantioselectivity the S-and R-forms of 2-hydroxy-1-phenylpropan-1-one (2-HPP) and 2-HPP analogues. The selectivity of BFD for the synthesis of (S )-2-HPP (while BAL catalyses the formation of (R)-2-HPP and the ortho-, para-and meta-substitutes) is limited for the wild type by the lack of activity on ortho-substituted benzaldehyde for the acyloin-type condensation to acetaldehyde (Scheme 7).

The directed evolution approach on BFD led to the isolation of two variants (L476Q and M365L-L461S) with striking improvements both in ee, from 82 to 93%, on originally processed substrates and acquisition of novel carboligase activity on benzaldehyde ortho substitutes with methyl, methoxy-, fluoro-, chloro-and bromo-groups (Table 1).

These (S )-2-HPP ortho-substitutes were synthesised by variant L476Q with ee > 99 and with 100% conversion within times suitable for preparative scale (20 h). Also the L476Q variant displayed an increase in carbo-ligase activity on benzaldehyde four-to five-fold higher than that of the wild type, also in the presence of 20% DMSO. The double mutant instead lost the carbo-ligase activity to the original substrate, but displayed equally good ee (>98%) with a degree of conversion from 46 to 100% on various ortho-substituted benzaldehydes for carboligation to acetaldehyde. A rational explanation might be suggested considering that L461 substitution with a serine could enlarge the active site. div.head: Isomerases
div.p: There are several interesting examples of applications of directed evolution to target enzymes of this class, including landmark papers on exploiting protein scaffold plasticity to accommodate different catalytic mechanisms. Although still controversial, the conceptual background of Fersht's work 106 on the α/β barrel scaffold exploitation for the evolution of phosphoribosilantranilate isomerase from indole 3-glycerophosphate synthase paved the way for other experiments of catalysis mechanism switching by directed evolution. The peculiar chemistry of isomerase reactions, borrowed by other enzyme classes, makes them the key examples for this approach, although similar switching of activity was also reported on the evolution of a tyrosine phosphatase from an arsenate reductase, 107 reverting the process that putatively led to the natural evolution of an arsenate resistance from phosphatase reaction chemistry.

The key point of common reaction chemistry for divergent natural evolution of enzymes is also the focus of a paper from Sterner and coworkers, 108 based on the evolution of a different catalytic activity on an α/β barrel scaffold, as for the approach mentioned above. In this case the authors were also putting to the test the so called "patchwork hypothesis" for enzyme evolution, suggesting that a common ancestor with low substrate specificity might have generated, by divergent evolution, different enzymes catalysing highly specific reactions. This would be the case for two isomerases, ProFAR isomerase (HisA) and PRA isomerase (TrpF) catalysing similar reactions in histidine and tryptophan metabolism respectively (Scheme 8).

The experimental approach aimed at generating variants of HisA from Thermotoga maritima able to act as TrpF but still retaining the original activity, thus reverting the natural evolution to produce the putative ancestor enzyme. The variant tHisA_1 was found to be originated by four substitutions, two lying close to the active site and two in far sites, acting in concert to establish a novel TrpF-like activity (although at low level) with retained HisA activity of 10% of the original k cat . The variant tHisA_2 (three aminoacids change) and the derived single mutant tHisA_Asp127Val show a complete inter-conversion of substrate specificity indicating that a single aminoacid change (Asp127Val) is responsible for the generation of two enzymes belonging to different metabolic pathways.

The active site redesign by rational directed mutagenesis was also applied to a similar catalysis switch, as for the case of a steroid double bond isomerase activity based on the GST. 74 The thiolate reaction chemistry, modified by adopting the thiol as a catalytic base in the new enzyme active site, allows the isomerisation instead of the redox reaction. The success of a rational approach is to be seen as a complement to maximise the full potential of protein engineering, as the modification of the active site often needs to be balanced distant mutations that are difficult to predict.

On a more applicative level the directed evolution of isomerases can generate variants with improved characteristics suitable for industrial processes, as in the case of xylose isomerase. This enzyme is commonly referred to as glucose isomerase and employed in the industrial conversion of glucose to fructose for example for production of syrup. The enzyme xylose isomerase from the hyperthermophile Thermotoga neapolitana (TNXI) was evolved 109 to select variants with a lower temperature optimum (60 ЊC) for catalysis and an increased stability at slightly acidic conditions, in order to fit the industrial process requirements (higher temperature can generate undesired by-products and alter syrup colour), with an advantage for catalysis given by the thermostability of the parental enzyme. Two variants were isolated (3A2 and 1F1) from a library generated by random mutagenesis on a TNXI single mutant V185T, previously produced and highly active at 97 ЊC. Both mutants were found to be three-fold more active than the TNXI V185T at their optimal temperatures of 95 ЊC and 90 ЊC. The activity at 60 ЊC was 7.3 times higher for 3A2 and 12.3 times higher for 1F1 when compared to TNXI, while at 90 ЊC the enhancement in activity was limited to a maximum of 4.8 times. This was attributed to a decrease in activation energy of the novel variants (57 kJ mol Ϫ1 for 3A4 and 44 kJ mol Ϫ1 for 1F1 versus 87 kJ mol Ϫ1 of TNXI). Significantly higher k cat were measured for both variants at 60 ЊC, and although the increase of K M affected the resulting catalytic efficiency, a 2.3-fold improvement was obtained for 1F1 compared to TNXI V185T at 60 ЊC. This is an important result in view of application to industrial processes, also given the retained thermostability of the variant.

div.head: Ligases
div.p: Members of this class of enzymes are widely used as research tools, for example polymerases are employed in academic as well as industrial research and they are also of valuable importance for diagnostics. This makes directed evolution of this class of enzymes very relevant to applications. An application of the compartmentalisation screening strategy described in section 3 37 led to a desirable increase of thermostability for Taq polymerase up to 11-fold compared to that of the wild type, with mutation clustering in the 5Ј-3Ј exonuclease domain in clone T8. Also variant H15 was isolated having an increased stability towards inhibition by the widely used anticoagulant heparin, a contaminant that hinders the application of PCR to clinical and forensic samples. The 130-fold enhanced resistance of clone H15 (fully active up to 1350 units heparin/ml) compared to wild type is linked to mutations (K225E, E388V, K540R, D578G, N583S, M747R) clustering in a region involved in the binding of a primer/template duplex, with no effect on the affinity for the duplex itself, but possibly decreasing affinity for heparin competitive binding. 37 From a more theoretical perspective, directed evolution was also applied to Taq DNA polymerases to test the possibility of evolving new functions such as RNA polymerase activity. In a paper from Romesberg and coworkers 110 three mutants were isolated to be efficient catalysts towards polymerisation using triphosphate ribonucleotides (rNTP) at rates comparable with those measured on the wild type using dNTPs. The variants were screened by displaying the polymerase on a filamentous phage and selecting for those able to incorporate rNTP and biotinylated UTP (assayed on a DNA template also anchored to the same phage surface) via recovery with streptavidin coated beads.

Another work from the same group is of relevant interest for biotechnological applications. 111 The paper describes the selection of evolved variants of polymerases able to catalyse the synthesis of 2Ј-O-methyl-modified polymers based on incorporation of rNTP. The screening procedure was similar to the one described above. The analysis of enzyme variants highlighted, for all mutated forms, the same degree of fidelity and comparable efficiency to the wild-type enzyme. The evolved enzymes maintained the essential interactions that the wt has with the DNA. The redesign of the active site, due to reorientation of critical side chains, specifically confers the novel capability of accepting the 2Ј-O-methyl-modified substrate.

Interesting implications for antiviral drugs can be foreseen in the strategy proposed in another paper 112 describing the evolution of a viral RNA polymerase from the bacteriophage T7 with specifically decreased fidelity rate (20-fold higher substitution error rate). This was achieved by carefully designing a screening procedure in which the error-prone activity is positively selected. The viral genomes are already replicated at the highest mutation rates that the viruses can tolerate, in order to maximise their infectivity. The evolved T7 polymerase was found to be able, in vivo, to interfere with the viral infection by decreasing the replication efficiency of wild type T7 bacteriophage.

div.head: Economic and applicative relevance
div.p: Several recent reviews highlighted the potential of directed evolution for industrial processes in which enzymes themselves can be either the final product to be commercialised 1,2,3,113,114, 115 or the products derived from evolved biocatalysts are used as fine chemicals (Table 2). 31,116-121 Most of the studies carried out in this field are in the process of being transferred to applications in the chemical and pharmaceutical industries. The crucial point is the timescale of the development of new enzymes by this method, that is still relatively slow when compared to the fast deadlines dictated by industry, that also require catalysts at low costs to be applied as largely as possible to many biotechnological applications. One of the leader companies in enzyme production for applications, Novozymes [www.novo-zymes.com], uses an approach to molecular evolution that is combined with powerful screening techniques able to supply new enzymes with the desired improved properties. The applications span from laundry to food production, bioremediation to animal feeding. In the year 2000 the enzyme market value was estimated to be over 1.5 billion dollars divided into: 1) a large sector (65%) of the so-called "technical enzymes", that are either additives to large selling products (detergents) or fundamental tools for large scale processes in leather, textile, pulp and paper industries; 2) a sector (25%) including enzymes employed in the food industry (baking, brewing, dairy) and 3) a smaller sector (10%) applied to the production of animal feeds. 1 The first enzymes to be chosen as a target for improvement of activity and stability by directed evolution were the proteases, amylases, and lipases. This is clearly justified by the wide and consolidated use of their wild type forms in large selling industries, such as detergents. Proteases, alone representing 35% of the total market for industrial enzymes, 1 lipases 122 and amylases, together with glucose isomerase, 123 are among the enzymes produced in the largest quantities (tons) and are used both as technical and food enzymes. It is worth noting that these enzymes were originally selected for industrial applications because of their high stability and catalytic activity, as they are in themselves excellent catalysts. Nonetheless, directed evolution offers the opportunity to explore novel sequence space and select functions and performance not achieved by natural evolution, and it was therefore used to improve even these catalysts. In these fields of application, even relatively low levels of enhancement in catalysis and/or stability under required process conditions results in substantial gain in performance and therefore in economically relevant gain. This is the case of Savinase ® (see section 2), a protease that is already suitable for commercial purposes, 22 where a two-to four-fold enhancement in activity after thermal treatment was obtained, together with other industrially important properties, leading to effective improvements in performance relevant to the market. Bacterial alkaline proteases have also been targets of directed evolution for industrial applications 124 including the commercialisation of specific variants (Durazym from Novozymes and Purafect from Genencor International Inc.).

A landmark example of application of directed evolution to commercial lipases is represented by the work of Borchert and coworkers at Novozymes 125 on Lipolase ® that was improved in its activity in the presence of detergents. At present Novozymes commercialises two variants of Lipolase ® obtained by protein engineering, Lipolase ® Ultra and LipoPrime, that also find applications in laundry detergents.

A recent work was published by a research group at Henkel 126 describing the directed evolution of an amylase from Bacillus amyloliquefaciens, for improvement of activity at the alkaline pH required for industrial processes in starch conversion, the pulp and paper industry and as a detergent additive. Error prone PCR and shuffling of the wt protein with two single mutants (S201N and N297D) led to the isolation of a variant showing a five-fold increase in activity at pH 10, while a second variant showing no changes in pH dependence was instead found to have a specific activity nine-fold higher than that of the wt.

Amylosucrase, an enzyme with potential in the field of modification of polysaccharides, was also evolved to have a five-fold improvement in its activity towards sucrose. 127 Other examples of industrially relevant targets improved by directed evolution include enzymes such as laccases, used in the textile and paper industries, 128 cellulases, hemicellulases, β-glycosidases 129 and endoglucanases evolved for thermostability. 130 Interestingly, the requirements for industrial processes include the evolution of enzymes from thermophilic organisms to obtain catalysts that also display optimal activity at lower temperatures. Phytase was also evolved to produce a "consensus phytase", 131 that represents a good example of a product from directed evolution transferred to the market: this enzyme has a significant economic impact, given its relevance for animal feeding, for releasing phosphorus and sequestered metals from plant phytate present at high percentages (50 to 80%) in pig and poultry feeds.

The chemical and pharmaceutical industries are mostly interested in the fine tuning of enzymatic properties for biocatalysis, a field where directed evolution counts several approaches and successful results, although not as many have been transferred to industrial processes. Several examples are reported of how directed evolution fits into the landscape of enzyme-based biocatalysis. 118 The major areas of interest are chiral and asymmetric synthesis, 132,133 involving lipases, esterases and phospholipases. 134, 135 The group of Reetz reported several examples of directed evolution applied to enhance the enantioselectivity of lipases. Several screening methods were designed by the same group in order to optimise the required properties of lipases and esterases with great relevance to selected synthesis of enantiopure intermediates. [136][137][138] An interesting new development suggested by Reetz concerns the appli-cation of directed evolution to develop hybrid catalysts for organic synthesis that cannot be enzymatically addressed at present. 120 This would require the implantation of transition metal centres suitable for selected organic transformations in a protein scaffold that would be able to tune chemo-, stereo and regio-selectivity, thus combining the power of organo-metallic and enzyme chemistry. The directed evolution approach would provide such hybrids with both the required plethora of scaffold variants and the screening methods for selective evolution of the best catalysts.
A considerable economic interest is also to be seen in potential applications of directed evolution to the development of novel or improved proteins to be used as biotherapeutics. 139

div.head: Relevance for nanobiotechnology and biosensors
div.p: Nanobiotechnology is a fast growing field of application where biomolecules are exploited for their intrinsically occurring functions at the nano-scale. In this respect directed evolution is a tool that holds great promise in being able to deliver proteins and enzymes designed and suited for specific applications. We already have seen key areas such as redox protein engineering combined with bioelectrochemistry showing a clear direction for exploitation. 140, 141 Directed evolution was applied earlier to the well characterised green fluorescent protein (GFP) from Aequorea victoria. 142 The intrinsic fluorophore present in GFP makes this protein a good reporter molecule. This has been linked to a calmodulin-based calcium sensor in which fluorescence resonance energy transfer is triggered by the large conformational changes occurring in calmodulin. A similar approach was applied to other protein-ligand systems that do not show conformational changes; for example the GFP was fused to a β-lactamase (Bla) gene so that this enzyme is inserted in an exposed loop of the GFP without structural-functional alterations and able to influence the fluorescence signal upon binding. In this case the ligand was represented by the β-Lactamase Inhibitory Protein (BLIP). The fusion protein GFP::Bla was subjected to random mutagenesis by epPCR and the library easily screened for fluorescent colonies expressing both the library and BLIP gene product. The GFP::Bla 1 variant was isolated and found to bear two point mutations in the Bla gene region (M681I and V108I). This retained the penicillinase activity with a k cat /K M of 2 × 10 6 M Ϫ1 s Ϫ1 , only one order of magnitude lower than that of the wild type Bla, and it was inhibited by BLIP with a K i of 0.2 µM, consistent with the K d of 0.35 µM determined independently by fluorescence. This paves the way to other applications such as various protein-ligand interaction sensing, ranging from hormones to metal detection in vitro and in vivo. A more recent work 143 applied directed evolution to the development of improved variants of a bacteriorodopsin (BR) from Halobacter salinarium for the development of commercially suitable optical memories configured in various devices from thin-film photochromic to Fourier transform holographic associative storage systems and branched-photocycle 3D-optical memories. The variables involved in bacteriorodopsin performance in such applications are difficult to rationalise in terms of protein structure, and limited information can be obtained from modelling approaches. For example in applications such as branchedphotocycle 3D-optical memories, improvements of bacteriorodopsin performance can be obtained by the synergic effect of minimal formation time and optimised decay of the O state, maximal quantum efficiency of photochemical transformation of O state to generate the first product of branching reaction (P), maximal efficiency of formation and high stability of the data storing Q state. Therefore, directed evolution of random or semi-random mutants is the election strategy to obtain further improvements 143 (to date up to 700-fold) of the performance of bacteriorodopsin as a volumetric memory medium for data storage.

A very recent review 144 foresees the application of directed evolution to redox enzymes for coupling to electrode surfaces and application to enzyme mediated electrocatalysis and sensing. In this respect interesting candidates are glucose oxidases, 145-147 laccases 148-151 and cytochrome P450s. 152 The projects developed by our group in this field provide tools for the application of directed evolution to nanobiotechnology. The combination of the "Molecular Lego" approach that aims to create artificial redox chains linked to electrode via flavodoxin, 153,154 together with the electrochemistry of engineered P450s 152 and the application of the "alkali assay" screening method 34 allowing screening for active P450 variants, provides an interesting synergic combination of directed evolution and rational design to create a novel generation of sensors based on laboratory evolved variants of P450s.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: The application of directed evolution to proteins and enzymes relevant to the fields of natural and unnatural product chemistry has already generated important achievements. A range of biocatalysts with novel and improved activity are now available for the most diverse synthesis and activities, from fine chemistry to laundry. The potential of enzymes as alternatives to classical chemical catalysts is today recognised 155 and is increasingly being implemented in industrial processes. Looking ahead into the future, the next challenge is to put to the test directed evolution in order to achieve extended coverage of organic synthesis by biocatalysts. In parallel the increasing number of enzymecatalysed reactions being scaled-up and developed as industrial processes will dictate novel requirements to the experimentalist in terms of enzyme stabilisation and tuning of activity. In terms of large-selling industrial biocatalysts, such as commercial lipases, proteases, esterases and phytases (Savinase ® , Lipolase ® Ultra and LipoPrime), the driving force imposed by the market is expected to lead further improvements by directed evolution, that was already demonstrated to be able to achieve unusually high levels of catalytic efficiency, even on excellent wild type biocatalysts.

Applications of directed evolution were recently foreseen 156 in one of the major organic chemistry reactions, the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation, a good example of asymmetric synthesis in which enzymes, NAD(P)H-and flavin-dependent "Baeyer-Villiger monooxygenases" (BVMO), greatly improved production with high ee values of complex organic molecules and key intermediates such as optically pure esters, lactones and sulfoxides. The application of BMVOs as isolate enzymes still finds limitations in enzyme stability and cofactor regeneration costs that can successfully be tackled further by directed evolution.

The selected examples of evolved variants of haloalkane dehalogenase, 99 toluene monooxygenase, 64 biphenyl dioxygenases 54,55, 56 and glutathione-S-transferase 75 demonstrated that another promising field of further development and application of evolved enzymes is detoxification of recalcitrant xenobiotics, with implications for bioremediation and environmental protection, but also with interesting links to pollution monitoring and biosensing. The screening procedures required for desired mutant identification and the large amount of variants with subtle differences in molecular recognition properties are within themselves excellent bases for the evolution of desired sensors in array format.

Multiple application fields are emerging for evolved variants in health-care, for protein-therapy, drug discovery and cell-protection against compounds applied in chemotherapy. In diagnostics, as in pollution monitoring, a combination of protein directed evolution with sensors and protein arrays development will be the research frontline in the near future.
